importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the third week of the ongoing government shutdown, highlighting the prolonged impact on federal workers and public services.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The shutdown has extended beyond initial expectations, affecting over 1.4 million federal employees who are now furloughed or working without pay.

keyTakeAways: More than 370 households received food assistance at a food bank event in Landover, Maryland, far exceeding expectations due to the scale of federal worker displacement during the shutdown.

Federal workers, including contractors and employees from agencies like the Department of Commerce and Social Security Administration, are facing financial hardship due to unpaid work and delayed paychecks.
The shutdown has disrupted the perceived stability of federal employment, with workers like Rolanda Williams acknowledging that federal jobs no longer guarantee financial security.

A bipartisan legislative effort is underway, with GOP Sen. Ron Johnson proposing to pay only those working during the shutdown, while Democrats advocate for universal payment to all federal employees.
The Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries organized a food distribution event requiring federal workers to present ID, revealing the widespread need for food aid during the crisis.

namedEntities.name: Summer Kerksick
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Federal contractor and market research analyst with the Rural Export Center, US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a representative example of a federal worker experiencing financial strain due to the shutdown, illustrating how even those in non-permanent roles are affected.

namedEntities.name: Ron Johnson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He introduced a bill to pay only federal workers who are required to work during the shutdown, reflecting a policy divide on how to address federal worker compensation.

namedEntities.name: Pamelia Carter
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Executive director of No Limits Outreach Ministries and a long-term employee at the Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She is a federal worker with 38 years of experience who observes the impact of shutdowns firsthand, adding a personal and historical perspective to the crisis.

namedEntities.name: Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Food bank in Washington, D.C. that partnered with No Limits Outreach Ministries
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It organized a large-scale food distribution event that revealed the severity of federal worker hardship, serving over 370 households beyond initial projections.

namedEntities.name: No Limits Outreach Ministries
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Local religious group that partnered with Capital Area Food Bank
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It played a critical role in organizing and executing a food outreach event for federal workers, highlighting community response to public emergency.

namedEntities.name: Rolanda Williams
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Employee at the Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: She exemplifies the shift in perception among federal workers, showing how financial insecurity has forced even stable employees to seek food assistance.

namedEntities.name: Rural Export Center
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Unit within the US Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is where Summer Kerksick works, illustrating that even specialized federal contractors are impacted by the shutdown and financial instability.

namedEntities.name: Department of Commerce
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It houses federal contractors and employees affected by the shutdown, contributing to the broader context of federal workforce disruption.

namedEntities.name: Department of Agriculture
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Pamelia Carter's long-term employment here shows how federal workers in key agencies face economic stress during shutdowns.

namedEntities.name: Social Security Administration
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is where Rolanda Williams works, illustrating how federal employees across agencies are experiencing financial hardship due to unpaid work.

summaryOfNewsArticle: As the government shutdown enters its third week, over 1.4 million federal workers—many of whom have been furloughed or are working without pay—face severe financial strain. A food bank event in Landover, Maryland, organized by the Capital Area Food Bank and No Limits Outreach Ministries, served more than 370 households, significantly exceeding expectations. Workers like Summer Kerksick and Rolanda Williams express shock at the loss of job security, with some having to rely on food pantries despite having previously considered themselves financially stable. The crisis has prompted legislative debate, with Republican Senator Ron Johnson proposing to pay only those working during the shutdown, while Democrats push for universal payment. The event underscores how federal employment, once seen as secure, is now exposed as vulnerable during prolonged shutdowns, highlighting both the human and systemic impacts of government gridlock.
title: Federal workers form line down the block for food pantry as shutdown hits third-week mark
